   No imaging for today.
   Assessment and Plan
   60 year old male with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the
   oropharynx and tongue is here in ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure
   and hypotension.
   .
   Started chemo [**8-17**] (taxotere), with planned several days 5FU. Was
   re-bronched [**8-18**] for anticipated clean out, but with underwhelming
   secretions - frothy - suspect cap leak [**1-19**] chemo), low CVP, required
   some pressors o/n, pan-cultured, pending. [**8-19**]: Worsening pulmonary
   edema post-BAL, responded well to diuresis and some increasing PEEP.
   [**8-20**]: Improvement with pulm edema/effusions c diuresis o/n with TBB
   negative -800, continuing to wean PEEP/O2. Leukocytosis improving,
   continuing ciprofloxacin through Sunday (for E. coli in BAL). Cont
   chemo (5FU). FiO2 and PEEP reduced - WBC trending down
   Overnight in ICU s/p Trach this AM - Tm 99.7 HR 80-104, SBP 91-166, RR
   11 Sat 95% PSV 5/PEEP 5/FiO2 .4, ABG 7.46/42/70. Sedated post-trach.
   Trach in place. Lungs cta, RRR, abd benign - PEG in place, ext no
   edema. Labs WBC 5.9K, HCT 27.4 PLT 105, K3.8, Cr .7. Cultures negative
   to date.
   Complex critically ill 60 yo man with invasive oral sq cell carcinoma
   currently requiring mechanical ventilatory support. We are treating
   with chemotherapy in hopes of reducing the size of the tumor. Our
   concern is that he will be getting neutropenic in the near future and
   we have completed his course of antibiotics. He is s/p trach and we
   will try to wean from mechanical ventilation to trach collar today.
   Continue nutrition via PEG. Will d/c CVL today.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Failure:  likely occurred secondary to aspiration
   pneumonia. Sputum was positive for pan-sensitive E.coli. Occurred in
   setting of RLL atelectasis/mucous plugging, HAP, worsening pulmonary
   effusions limiting re-expansion of the lung love.  Patient now
   intubated nasotracheally, on PS and stable.  Barriers to extubation
   include poor clearance of oral secretions due to oral opening and
   sedation, and tumor burden in the oropharynx and tongue, necessitating
   a trach. Even if he can be safely extubated, he likely will need trach
   anyway given his risk of aspiration in the setting of high tumor burden
   and nausea associated with his future chemo therapy. With his WBC
   trending down, It wold be safer to trach pt when his WBC is still
   within normal range. Also, would not be ideal to leave a nasotracheal
   tube in when pt is leukopenic.
   - consult IP and radiology for possible trach this weekend
   - switch to levoflox for resp infection (tomorrow is the last day)
   - decrease FiO2 to 40% as tolerated
   - continue to attempt decrease his ventilator dependence
   .
   # B/L effusions: initially increased in setting of fluid resuscitation,
   given low albumin.  Improved after gentle diurese using albumin and
   lasix.  Now slightly more effusions on CXR.
   - continue current vent settings with PS, mdis and pulm toliet.
   - Attemp goal of 1L negative balance today
   .
   # Squamous Cell Carcinoma of oropharynx and tongue:  continue
   chemotherapy.
   - continue chemo
   - touch base with oncology regarding recommendations
   - finish last day of 5-FU (started on [**8-17**])
   - touch base with oncology regarding the interaction between chemo
   drugs and all the vitamins he is currently receiving
   .
   # Septic Shock:  Resolved. Likley secondary to sepsis in setting of
   pneumonia.  BP stable overnight, no pressors requirement.  Currently
   with PICC line and CVL for access.
   - f/u with oncology recs considering length of CVL placement
   - switch to levoflox for resp infection (tomorrow is the last day)
   - Normotensive overnight.  Continue to monitor urine outpt
   - IVF boluses for target MAP > 60, UOP > 30 cc/hr
   - followup blood, urine, sputum, and stool cultures
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Now trending down, heading toward leukopenia. Likely
   secondary to chemotherapy.
   - continue to monitor
   # Malnutrition:  Patient presented with dehydration now s/p PEG tube
   placement for nutritional support.
   - continue tube feeds
   - nutrition following
   # Anemia:  Back at baseline hematocrit, which is in the high 20s.
   Normocytic.  Unclear etiology but in setting of malignancy, and
   ileostomy, with possible nutritional deficiencies. Anemia of
   inflammation also plays a role. He is not in DIC, not hemolyzing, and
   presents with low reticulocyte count.
   - active type and screen
   - consider transfusion if ScVO2 below 70
   - continue iron supplements, folate for now, touch base with oncology
   whether they interfere with chemotherapy.
   # Hyponatremia: Currently stable. Possibly [**1-19**] hypovolemia vs SIADH (in
   the setting of squamous cell ca of lung vs. pulmonary process). Urine
   Na 25 and Urine Osm 798.
   - continue to monitor
   # Back Pain:
   - fentanyl for sedation and pain control while intubated
   # GERD:
   - continue lansoprazole
   # Depression:
   - continue bupropion and citalopram

Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:
- The patient is a 60-year-old male with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx and tongue.
- He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotension.
- The patient underwent several interventions, including tracheostomy, initiation of chemotherapy (taxotere and 5FU), and placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube for nutrition.
- He also received antibiotics for an E. coli infection in the bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL).
- The patient's condition has fluctuated, with periods of improvement and worsening.
- He has been experiencing pulmonary edema, which responded to diuretics and increased PEEP.
- His white blood cell count (WBC) has been trending down, indicating a possible future risk of neutropenia.
- The patient's vital signs have been stable, with a blood pressure range of 91-166 mmHg, heart rate (HR) between 80-104 beats per minute, respiratory rate (RR) around 11 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) at 95%.
- Laboratory results show anemia, hyponatremia, and malnutrition.
- The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation support and is expected to be weaned off soon.
- The plan is to switch to levofloxacin for respiratory infection and continue chemotherapy.

The patient's current condition includes hypoxic respiratory failure, bilateral effusions, septic shock (resolved), leukocytosis (trending down), malnutrition, anemia, hyponatremia, back pain, GERD, and depression. He is intubated nasotracheally and on positive pressure ventilation. His vital signs are stable, and he is receiving various medications for pain, sedation, and infection prophylaxis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if there is further aspiration pneumonia or inadequate clearance of oral secretions.
2. Bilateral Effusions: The effusions may increase in size or worsen, potentially compromising lung re-expansion and leading to further respiratory distress.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is decreasing but may continue to trend towards leukopenia due to chemotherapy. This increases the risk of infection.
4. Malnutrition: The patient's nutritional status may deteriorate without adequate enteral support.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen due to ongoing blood loss, chemotherapy, or nutritional deficiencies.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium levels may continue to fluctuate, potentially leading

3. Leukocytosis: The patient initially had leukocytosis, which is now trending down and heading toward leukopenia. This is likely secondary to chemotherapy.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 60-year-old male with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx and tongue admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotension.
- The patient has been diagnosed with aspiration pneumonia, which likely caused the hypoxic respiratory failure. The sputum was positive for pan-sensitive E. coli.
- The patient underwent tracheostomy and is currently on a trach collar.
- The patient has bilateral pleural effusions, which improved after gentle diuresis using albumin and lasix.
- The patient's septic shock has resolved, and the current focus is on monitoring urine output and blood pressure.
- The patient is expected to be transferred to the floor today.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient initially experienced hypoxic respiratory failure due to aspiration pneumonia. It is important to monitor the patient's oxygen saturation levels and ensure adequate ventilation.
2. Bilateral Pleural Effusions: The patient has had persistent bilateral pleural effusions. This can be managed by continuing gentle diuresis and monitoring fluid balance.
3. Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Oropharynx and Tongue: The patient has ongoing treatment for squamous cell carcinoma. Regular follow-up with oncology is necessary to monitor the effectiveness of chemotherapy and watch for neutropenia.
4. Leukocytosis/Leukopenia: The patient's white blood cell count

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx and tongue. He is currently in the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotension. The patient has undergone several interventions, including tracheostomy, placement of a PEG tube for nutritional support, and CVL placement for access. He is being treated for aspiration pneumonia caused by pan-sensitive E. coli and has shown improvement after gentle diuresis using albumin and lasix. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he continues to require mechanical ventilation. His lab results show leukocytosis trending down, heading toward leukopenia likely secondary to chemotherapy, as well as anemia, malnutrition, hyponatremia, and back pain. He is also being managed for GERD, depression, and stress ulcers. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP. Monitoring for symptoms such as fever, increased production of purulent secretions, and worsening oxygenation is important.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and the presence of central venous lines increase the risk of DVT. Regular assessment of peripheral pulses, skin changes, and monitoring of D-dimer levels can help identify this complication.
3. Pressure ulcers: Prolonged bed rest and impaired mobility

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is a 60-year-old male with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx and tongue.
- He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and hypotension.
- The patient has undergone tracheostomy due to poor clearance of oral secretions and tumor burden in the oropharynx and tongue.
- He is currently on mechanical ventilation, but efforts are being made to wean him off the ventilator and transition to tracheostomy collar support.
- The patient has pneumonia caused by pan-sensitive E. coli, and antibiotics have been switched from ciprofloxacin to levofloxacin.
- Bilateral effusions were initially present but have improved after diuresis using albumin and lasix.
- The patient is receiving chemotherapy for his squamous cell carcinoma.
- He had septic shock that has resolved, likely secondary to pneumonia. He is now stable without the need for pressors.
- The patient has leukocytosis, which is trending down, possibly secondary to chemotherapy.
- He is also experiencing malnutrition, anemia, hyponatremia, back pain, GERD, and depression.
- The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.9°C (100.3°F), heart rate of 102 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 119/59 to 131/
